Homework (due 0304)

Complete these for Monday, March 4. Show work that justifies your answers for full credit.

  1. Find the angle from \(l_1\) to \(l_2\) with slopes \(m_1\) and \(m_2\), respectively:

    1. \(m_1=-2\) and \(m_2=3\)

      Using \(\tan\alpha=\frac{3--2}{1+(-2)(3)}=-1\), we get that \(\alpha\) is exactly \(-45^\circ.\) The angle \(135^\circ\) is also correct.

    2. \(m_1=1\) and \(m_2=4\)

      Using \(\tan\alpha=\frac{4-1}{1+(1)(4)}=\frac{3}{5}\), we get that \(\alpha\) is approximately \(31^\circ.\) The angle \(-149^\circ\) is also correct.

    3. \(m_1=-3\) and \(m_2=2\)

      Using \(\tan\alpha=\frac{2--3}{1+(-3)(2)}=-1\), we get that \(\alpha\) is exactly \(-45^\circ.\) The angle \(135^\circ\) is also correct.

    4. \(m_1=0\) and \(m_2=1\)

      Using \(\tan\alpha=\frac{1-0}{1+(0)(1)}=1\), we get that \(\alpha\) is exactly \(45^\circ.\) The angle \(-135^\circ\) is also correct.

  2. Find the angle from \(l_1\) with slope \(m_1\) to the vertical:

    1. \(m_1=10\)

      The line \(l_1\) with slope \(m_1\) has an inclination of approximately \(\tan^{-1}(10)\approx 84^\circ.\) To get to vertical, a \(6^\circ\) counterclockwise rotation or \(-174^\circ\) clockwise rotation is needed.

    2. \(m_1=-2/3\)

      The line \(l_1\) with slope \(m_1\) has an inclination of approximately \(\tan^{-1}(-2/3)+180^\circ \approx 146^\circ.\) To get to vertical, a \(-56^\circ\) clockwise rotation or \(127^\circ\) counterclockwise rotation is needed.

  3. Find the interior angles of the triangle with vertices \((1,5)\), \((3,-1)\), and \((-1,1)\), rounded to the nearest degree.

    The slopes of the three sides are \(-3,\) \(-1/2,\) and \(2,\) as shown in the following picture.

    Since \(-1/2\) and \(2\) are opposite reciprocals, the angle at \((-1,1)\) is \(90^\circ.\) We calculate the angle at \((1,5)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-3-2}{1+(-3)(2)}\right)=45^\circ.\) We calculate the angle at \((3,-1)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-1/2--3}{1+(-3)(-1/2)}\right)=45^\circ.\) Thus we have found the three interior angles exactly (no need to round). The sum of the angles is \(180^\circ,\) so that is consistent with this being a correct answer.

  4. Find the slope of line \(l_1\) where the angle from \(l_1\) to \(l_2\) is \(45^\circ\) and the slope of \(l_2\) is \(m_2=1/2\).

    Using the formula for the angle from one line to another, we have the equation \(\tan(45^\circ)=\frac{1/2-m_1}{1+m_1(1/2)}.\) Then \(1=\frac{1/2-m_1}{1+(1/2)m_1}.\) Then \(1/2-m_1=1+(1/2)m_1.\) Then \(-1/2=(3/2)m_1\). Then \(m_1=-1/3,\) which is the slope of \(l_1.\)

  5. Use slopes and angles, not the length of sides, to show that \((-1,0)\), \((4,6)\), and \((10,1)\) are the vertices of an isosceles triangle. Hint: a triangle is defined to be isosceles when it has at least two congruent sides, but it is also true that a triangle is isosceles when it has at least two congruent angles.

    The slopes of the three sides are \(-5/6,\) \(1/11,\) and \(6/5,\) as shown in the following picture.

    It looks like the angles at vertex \(A\) and vertex \(C\) might be congruent. We calculate the angle at \(A(-1,0)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{6/5-1/11}{1+(1/11)(6/5)}\right)=45^\circ.\) We calculate the angle at \(C(10,1)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{1/11--5/6}{1+(-5/6)(1/11)}\right)=45^\circ.\) Thus the angles at vertex \(A\) and vertex \(C\) are congruent. Therefore this is an isosceles triangle.

  6. Use slopes and angles to classify each of the following triangles as acute, obtuse, or right.

    1. \((-1,0)\), \((4,6)\), and \((10,1)\)

      The slopes of the three sides are \(-5/6,\) \(1/11,\) and \(6/5,\) as shown in the following picture.

      The slopes \(-5/6\) and \(6/5\) are opposite reciprocals, so this triangle has a right angle at vertex \((4,6).\) Therefore, it is a right triangle.

    2. \((9,6)\), \((-5,4)\), and \((7,10)\)

      The slopes of the three sides are \(1/7,\) \(1/4,\) and \(-2,\) as shown in the following picture.

      We calculate the angle at \(C(7,10)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-2-1/4}{1+(1/4)(-2)}\right)+180^\circ\approx 103^\circ.\) This triangle has an obtuse angle, and so, it must be an obtuse triangle.

    3. \((-2,1)\), \((-1,-5)\), and \((2,-3)\)

      The slopes of the three sides are \(2/3,\) \(-1,\) and \(-6,\) as shown in the following picture.

      We calculate the angle at \(A(-2,1)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-1--6}{1+(-1)(-6)}\right)\approx 34^\circ.\)

      We calculate the angle at \(B(-1,-5)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-6-2/3}{1+(2/3)(-6)}\right)\approx 66^\circ.\)

      We calculate the angle at \(C(2,-3)\) as follows: \(\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{2/3--1}{1+(-1)(2/3)}\right)\approx 79^\circ.\)

      Since all three angles are acute, this is an acute triangle. (These three add up to only \(179^\circ\) because of rounding.)
